1080437578669658114.text: 1b) if not, what are the building blocks you can work on which makes it easier for people to exit a system and develop their own in a relatively peaceful way? Should you focus on that instead of building a new institution from scratch?

1080437577268846598.text: (Some of these groups will be terrible steps backwards if they gain prominence, some of these will appear to be steps backwards because they’re subversive and different but actually offer a path towards better life. Which is which?)

1080437575817617408.text: 1a) if yes, are there groups out there that people are not paying attention to who are equivalent to the aforementioned hermits and who are developing powerful, subversive and contagious values/ideas?

1080437574475358209.text: 1) is it possible today for someone to opt out of society/a value system?

1080437572717944832.text: To me, this opens up a few questions for anyone who has thought about institutions or value systems which don’t seem well adapted to the modern world, and need either updating or replacement:

1080437570952196096.text: At the same time, could we really have expected thoughts and values as subversive as Christian thoughts were to occur if you had to build The Church, and collapse an empire before you could start having people live by your new rules?

1080437569496772608.text: It seems likely to me that very few people who lived under the influence and benefited from churches and monasteries in the 11th or 12th century would have been motivated enough to exit society like hermits, or even agreed with the more extreme values or beliefs of early hermits

1080437567902801924.text: These monastic communities developed into an incredibly powerful (sometimes overly) cultural dissemination tool, especially after the collapse of the roman empire

1080437566409723905.text: Despite them living apart from society, they formed trade links and small communities, gradually attracting people to their way of life, and gradually organising into monastic-like communities

1080437564983689216.text: They were able both to live an uncompromising life not anchored to the prevalent values of the time, and serve as as a “reference implementation” of a new value system

1080437563553398785.text: The (abridged) argument goes: hermits, reacting to what they perceived to be a conflict between their value system and the world’s, removed themselves from the current social system physically and mentally

1080437560567087104.text: Reading Inventing the Individual, one of the things it’s made me think the most about are hermits and the early monasticism, and the importance those two movements had in propagating a new value system (this is still unformed, so forgive flaws and call them out!)

978894890280148992.text: So internet institutions have been able to build up a healthy push back to the desires of the mainstream. How can crypto achieve the same thing, given it's ideals?

978894566303633408.text: I've been really influenced by @nfergus on this: weak concentration of power is good if you want new orders to emerge, but to allow those new orders to stay stable, you have to concentrate power in a way which makes whims of the group less impactful

978894565099831297.text: But I worry that while internet institutions have always had some central leadership (despite the idealism), crypto is pushing for no central leadership at all

978894563556429825.text: I guess the flipside is that the mainstream's desires around governance of internet institutions came about within a vastly different context to the one idealistic early adopters experienced. So them pushing for change is healthy.

978893373997289472.text: One thing I've been thinking about: early-ish adopters of the internet seem to have been surprised at how the mainstream wants to govern internet institutions. Will it be the same for crypto? Is there an existential risk to not define governance methods strictly early?
